<style>.footnotes::before { content: "Footnotes:"; }</style>
# Public Prosecutor _v_ Boldbaatar Odonchimeg  

### \[2022\] SGDC 201

<table id="info-table"><tbody><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Case Number</td><td class="txt-body">District Arrest Case No 910489 of 2022 &amp; ors, Magistrate's Appeal No 9146-2022-01</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Decision Date</td><td class="txt-body">02 September 2022</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Tribunal/Court</td><td class="txt-body">District Court</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Coram</td><td class="txt-body">Kamala Ponnampalam</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Counsel Name(s)</td><td class="txt-body">Mr Chia Cheng Yi Andrew (Attorney-General's Chambers) for the Public Prosecutor; Accused in Person.</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Parties</td><td class="txt-body">Public Prosecutor — Boldbaatar Odonchimeg</td></tr></tbody></table>

Criminal Procedure and Sentencing – Sentencing – Offence under Section 332 Penal Code – Voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty – Whether sentence of imprisonment is warranted Criminal Procedure and Sentencing – Sentencing – Offence under Section 6(1)(a) Protection from Harassment Act – Whether sentence is manifestly excessive

\[LawNet Editorial Note: An appeal to this decision has been filed in MA 9146/2022/01.\]

2 September 2022

### District Judge Kamala Ponnampalam:

1       This is an appeal against sentence by the Accused person, Boldbaatar Odonchimeg (“the Accused”). The Accused is a female, Mongolian national, aged 35 years. She faced four charges. On 8 August 2022, she pleaded guilty to two charges and consented to have the two remaining charges taken into consideration for purposes of sentencing. The two proceeded charges are:

> (a)     voluntarily causing hurt to deter a public servant from his duty under Section 332 Penal Code (Cap 224, Rev Ed 2008) (“s 332 PC”); and

> (b)     using abusive words on a public servant in relation to the execution of his duty under Section 6(1)(a) p/u Section 6(3) Protection from Harassment Act (Cap 256A, Rev Ed 2015) (“s 6(1) POHA”).

2       The two charges taken into consideration for purposes of sentencing are:

> (a)     voluntarily causing hurt to deter a public servant from his duty under Section 332 Penal Code (Cap 224, Rev Ed 2008); and

> (b)     being drunk in a public place and causing annoyance under Section 14(2) Liquor Control (Supply and Consumption) Act 2015 (Act 5 of 2015).

3       The details of the charges and the sentences imposed are shown in the table below.

![](data:image;base64,)

4       The Accused conducted her own defence in the Mongolian language. She entered her plea of guilt and delivered her mitigation plea through a Mongolian speaking interpreter.

## Facts

5       On 6 December 2021 at about 8.45 pm, the Accused was at a coffeeshop located at 1018 Sembawang Road, Singapore (the “Coffeeshop”). The Accused was intoxicated at the time and was causing annoyance at the Coffeeshop. Police were despatched to the Coffeeshop but the Accused was uncooperative, aggressive and had to be restrained with handcuffs. She was placed in a police vehicle and transported to the Regional Lockup located at the Woodlands Division Police Headquarters.

6       Throughout the journey, the Accused struggled and behaved aggressively towards the two escorting officers, Senior Staff Sergeant Dhanaletchmi D/O Kuppusamy (“SSS Dhana”), and Corporal Muhammad Islam Angullia Bin Yussoff (“Cpl Islam”). SSS Dhana had to sit next to the Accused in the police vehicle and hold onto her right thigh and right shoulder throughout the journey.

7       When they arrived at the Woodlands Division Police Headquarters, the Accused continued to behave aggressively. She was uncooperative and was shouting at the police officers. The Accused then uttered vulgarities directed at SSS Dhana and kicked Cpl Islam in the groin area. Cpl Islam sought medical attention at the Khoo Teck Puat Hospital (“KTPH”). The medical report from KTPH revealed that Cpl Islam had suffered a contusion of his perineum. He was discharged with advice and given two days of medical leave. The analysis of the Accused’s blood sample obtained after her arrest revealed a blood alcohol concentration of 159 mg/100ml.

## The Charges

8       The Accused’s conduct resulted in four charges being preferred against her. The Prosecution proceeded on two of the charges which are reproduced below for ease of reference.

> DAC 910489-2022:

>> … are charged that you, on the 6 December 2021, at or about 10:03 pm, at the Regional Lockup located at 1 Woodlands Street 12, Woodlands Division Police Headquarters, Singapore 738622, did voluntarily cause hurt to one SC/CORPORAL Muhammad Islam Angullia Bin Yusoff, a public servant employed under the office of Singapore Police Force, by using your right leg to kick the said public servant in the groin area, with intent to deter the said public servant from discharging his duty as a public servant and you have thereby committed an offence punishable under Section 332 of the Penal Code, Chapter 224.

> MAC 904682-2022

>> … are charged that you, on the 6 December 2021, at or about 9:52 pm, at the Regional Lockup located at 1 Woodlands Street 12, Woodlands Division Police Headquarters, Singapore 738622, did used abusive words towards one Senior Staff Sergeant Dhanaletchmi d/o Kuppusamy (the “Officer”), a public servant employed under the office of the Singapore Police Force, in relation to the execution of her duty as such public servant, _to wit_, while in the custody of the Officer, uttered vulgarities at her such as, “fucking don’t touch me”, “you don’t touch me bitch” and “fuck you okay”, with intent to deter the Officer from discharging her duty as a public servant, and you have thereby committed an offence under Section 6(1)(a) punishable under Section 6(3) of the Protection from Harassment Act, Chapter 256A.

## Antecedents

9       The Accused has dissimilar antecedents.

<table align="left" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="Judg-2-tblr"><colgroup><col width="8.48169633926785%"><col width="30.5061012202441%"><col width="30.4860972194439%"><col width="30.5261052210442%"></colgroup><tbody><tr><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b>S/N</b></p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b>Date of Conviction</b></p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b>Offence and offence provision</b></p></td><td align="left" class="b" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b>Sentence Imposed</b></p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">1.</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">26/04/2018</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Drink driving</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">S 67(1)(b) RTA, Cap 276.</p></td><td align="left" class="b" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Fine $3,000. Disqualified for 24 mths.</p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">3.</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">26/04/2018</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Taking vehicle w/o owner’s consent</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">S 96(1) RTA, Cap. 276</p></td><td align="left" class="b" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">TIC</p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="r" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">4.</p></td><td align="left" class="r" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">26/04/2018</p></td><td align="left" class="r" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Careless driving</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">S 65(b) RTA, Cap. 276</p></td><td align="left" class="" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">TIC</p></td></tr></tbody></table>

  
  

## Prosecution’s address on sentence

10     The Prosecution submitted for a global sentence of at least 12 weeks’ imprisonment. The table below summarises the Prosecution’s sentencing position.

<table align="left" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="Judg-2-tblr" frame="all" pgwide="1"><colgroup><col width="13.82%"><col width="44.66%"><col width="41.52%"></colgroup><tbody><tr><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Offence</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Prescribed punishment</p></td><td align="left" class="b" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Prosecution’s submission</p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">s 332 PC</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Imprisonment for a term which may extend to 7 years, and shall also be liable to fine or to caning, provided that in exceptional circumstances imprisonment need not be imposed</p></td><td align="left" class="b" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">At least 12 weeks’ imprisonment</p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">s 6(1) POHA</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">A fine not exceeding $5,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12&nbsp;months or to both</p></td><td align="left" class="b" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">At least 1 week’s imprisonment</p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="r" colspan="2" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Global sentence</p></td><td align="left" class="" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">At least 12 weeks’ imprisonment</p></td></tr></tbody></table>

  
  

11     For the s 332 PC charge, Prosecution relied on the sentencing framework set out in _PP v Yeo Ek Boon Jeffrey_ <span class="citation">\[2018\] 3 SLR 1080</span> (“_Jeffrey Yeo_”). It was submitted that the sentencing framework in _Jeffrey Yeo_ applied to offenders who (1) caused hurt to police officers under s 332 PC, (2) pleaded guilty, and (3) do not have relevant criminal antecedents. The sentencing framework, as shown below, comprised three broad sentencing bands based on the twin considerations of harm and culpability.

<table align="left" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="Judg-2-tblr" frame="all" pgwide="1"><colgroup><col width="15.376924615077%"><col width="45.3309338132374%"><col width="39.2921415716857%"></colgroup><tbody><tr><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b>Category</b></p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b>Circumstances</b></p></td><td align="left" class="b" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b>Sentencing band</b></p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">1</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Lesser harm and lower culpability</p></td><td align="left" class="b" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Fine or up to one year’s imprisonment</p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">2</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Greater harm and lower culpability or</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Lesser harm and higher culpability</p></td><td align="left" class="b" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">One to three years’ imprisonment</p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="r" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">3</p></td><td align="left" class="r" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Greater harm and higher culpability</p></td><td align="left" class="" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Three to seven years’ imprisonment</p></td></tr></tbody></table>

  
  

12     In the context of an offence under s 332 PC, the degree of harm caused would refer to the nature and gravity of the hurt caused to the particular police officer and the consequences to the police in general. The degree of culpability is measured chiefly in relation to the manner and the motivation of the offender’s involvement in the criminal act. Once the appropriate sentencing band is determined using the harm-culpability matrix, further adjustments should be made to take into consideration other relevant aggravating and mitigating factors.

13     Applying the framework to the present case, the Prosecution submitted that the present case falls under Category 1 as it involves lesser harm and the Accused’s culpability was low. In relation to harm, the assessment was based on the following factors:

> (a)     Minor injuries were caused to the police officer, Cpl Islam. Cpl Islam suffered contusion of his perineum and was given two days of medical leave.

> (b)     The level of harm caused in the present case is slightly higher than that in _Jeffrey Yeo_, where the offender slapped the police officer on the right cheek. The officer sustained “tenderness over his left cheek and abrasion over the left shin” which the High Court held to constitute slight harm.

> (c)     Additionally, the hurt to Cpl Islam was caused within the premises of the Woodlands Regional Lockup, out of public view and hearing. In those circumstances, there would be no prospect of a possible erosion of public respect for the authority of the police.

14     In relation to culpability:

> (a)     Similar to the offender in _Jeffrey Yeo_, the Accused was drunk, vulgar towards the police, and a nuisance prior to and throughout the incident.

> (b)     However, the accused’s culpability should be higher than the offender in _Jeffrey Yeo_ given the circumstances in which the offence occurred. When the police first approached the accused, she was disturbing public peace at the Coffeeshop. She had continued to disobey police instructions throughout the incident and had struggled constantly with Cpl Islam and SSS Dhana. In contrast, the offender in _Jeffrey Yeo_ was lying asleep on a grass patch near a canal next to a road and was not causing trouble; there were no members of the public in the vicinity.

15     The Prosecution added that the following offender-specific factors must then be taken into account in calibrating the sentence to be imposed.

> (a)     The accused is traced, albeit for unrelated antecedents; and

> (b)     The accused elected to plead guilty at the earliest opportunity.

16     Notably, these offender-specific factors were also present in _Jeffrey Yeo_.

17     Taking into account the above offence-specific and offender-specific factors, the Prosecution arrived at a sentence of at least 12 weeks’ imprisonment, slightly higher than the sentence of ten weeks’ imprisonment imposed on the offender in _Jeffrey Yeo_.

18     The Prosecution next submitted for a sentence of at least one week’s imprisonment for the s 6(1) POHA charge. The Prosecution relied on the sentencing precedents listed in the table below and argued that the usual sentence for a s 6(1) POHA charge is a short custodial sentence or a fine. The custodial threshold is crossed in this case as:

> (a)     the accused was intoxicated at the time of committing the offence; and

> (b)     the accused uttered abusive words towards the victim on three occasions.

19     The Prosecution cited four sentencing precedents.

<table align="left" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="Judg-2-tblr" frame="all" pgwide="1"><colgroup><col width="16.7433486697339%"><col width="47.629525905181%"><col width="16.8233646729346%"><col width="18.8037607521504%"></colgroup><tbody><tr><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b>Case</b></p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b>Facts</b></p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b>Antecedents</b></p></td><td align="left" class="b" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b>Outcome</b></p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b><em>PP v Navinthiren Moses s/o Krishna </em></b><b>[2021]</b></p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b>SGDC 110</b></p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Proceeded:</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">2x s 332 Penal Code 1x s 6(1)(a) punished under s 6(3) POHA</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">TIC: 2x s 353 Penal Code</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">The offender and a group of 15 to 20 people were gathered at a barbeque pit to celebrate the offender’s birthday. The victim and her colleagues, all from the Singapore Police Force, asked the group to lower their volume. The offender and a friend approached two of the police officers and challenged them about the law. The victim joined the other two police officers and tried to calm the offender down. The offender shouted “fuck you lah” to her in English.</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">None</p></td><td align="left" class="b" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">$2,000 in default one week’s imprisonment (Appeal discontinued)</p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b><em>PP v Leong Yin Teng Coretta and ors </em></b><b><a class="pagecontent" href="javascript:viewPageContent('/Judgment/24730-SSP.xml')">[2020] SGDC 154</a></b></p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">The victim and his colleagues, all from the Singapore Police Force, conducted a routine raid at various clubs in St James Power Station. The offender spoke to the victim in an aggressive tone and uttered “fuck you, chee bye” at the victim.</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">None</p></td><td align="left" class="b" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">$2,500 fine, i/d 10 days’ imprisonment (Appeal</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">dismissed)</p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b><em>PP v Ng Eong</em></b></p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b><em>Chien </em></b><b><a class="pagecontent" href="javascript:viewPageContent('/Judgment/22786-SSP.xml')">[2019] SGDC 16</a></b></p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><u>Proceeded:</u></p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">1x s 353 Penal Code</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">2x s 6(1)(a) punished under s 6(3) POHA</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><u>TIC:</u></p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">2x s 6(1)(a) punished under s 6(3) POHA</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">The offender pleaded guilty to two charges under s 6(1)(a) POHA punished under s 6(3) POHA.</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">The police officers were on patrol duty around Beach Road when they found the offender sleeping at the side of the road. They were concerned for his safety and tried to wake him up. After the officers identified themselves as police officers to the offender, one of the officers asked for the offender’s particulars. The offender shouted at him to “shut the fuck up”. When the officer warned the offender to keep the peace, the offender shouted again at the officer to “shut the fuck up”. The offender started to walk away, and when the officer tried to stop the offender from leaving, the offender called him “Si Pui Eh” (i.e. dead fatty) and shouted “Kan Ni Na Bu Chao Chee Bye” (i.e. Fuck your mother’s smelly vagina). This formed the first charge.</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">After the offender was arrested, he was escorted back to the Police Cantonment Complex in a police car. One of the officers asked the offender what he did which led to his arrest. The offender verbally abused Sgt Joel “shut the fuck up, police dog”.</p></td><td align="left" class="br" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Traced for multiple antecedents though none directly relevant. First conviction was for theft, mischief and rioting in 2005, last conviction for importing uncustomed goods in 2014.</p></td><td align="left" class="b" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">1 week’s imprisonment for each charge (Appeal</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">dismissed)</p></td></tr><tr><td align="left" class="r" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b><em>PP v Rasaruddin</em></b></p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b><em>Bin Abdul</em></b></p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b><em>Rahaman </em></b><b>[2017]</b></p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><b>SGDC 205</b></p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1"><u>Proceeded</u></p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">1x s 6(1)(a) punished under s 6(3) POHA.</p><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">1x s 353 Penal Code.</p></td><td align="left" class="r" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">The offender was scheduled to be released from prison. When preparing for the offender‘s release, the victim, a public servant, found several unofficial documents on the offender. The victim explained to the offender that he was not allowed to bring these documents out. The Assistant Superintendent of the prison stepped in and informed the offender that he could not bring these documents out and took the documents away. The victim continued to escort the offender out of the prison. Feeling unhappy, the offender said “Puki Mak” in Malay language to the victim, which is translated to mean “Mother’s cunt” in English.</p></td><td align="left" class="r" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">Traced for multiple antecedents though none directly relevant. First conviction was for failure to report for urine test in 1982, last conviction for theft in 2005.</p></td><td align="left" class="" rowspan="1" valign="top"><p align="justify" class="Table-Para-1">1 week’s imprisonment (Upheld on appeal)</p></td></tr></tbody></table>

  
  

## Mitigation Plea

20     The Accused set out her personal circumstances and pleaded for a sentence of a fine only. She stated that she has a 16-year old daughter and she was married to her husband in 2019. She had been away from her mother and her family for a long time, for about three years following the lockdown due to the Covid-19 pandemic. As a result, she fell into depression. This caused her to get into trouble with the law. She regrets her actions and has been seeking help at the Toa Payoh Care 15 Corner. Her counsellor is Mr Ron Tan and her husband ensures that she attends the counselling sessions and accompanies her to the sessions. The Accused added that she had suffered a miscarriage in May and was going through post-natal stress. She expressed her remorse and pleaded for leniency. She reiterated her plea for a fine only so that she could be reunited with her family and her condition could improve as well.

## Decision on sentence

21     The central question in this case was whether the offences merit a custodial sentence. I was of the firm view that the custodial threshold was crossed for the s 332 PC offence and the Prosecution’s proposed sentence of at least 12 weeks’ imprisonment was fair. However, I was not persuaded that the s 6(1) POHA offence warranted a custodial sentence. I set out my reasons below.

### s 332 PC offence

22     I agree with the Prosecution’s assessment that the present case would fall within Category 1 of the sentencing framework set out in _Jeffrey Yeo_. The factual matrix in the present case is very similar to that in _Jeffrey Yeo_.

23     The offender in _Jeffrey Yeo_ pleaded guilty to a single charge under s 332 PC for voluntarily causing hurt to deter a public servant from his duty. The victim, a police officer, and his partner, found the offender lying on a grass patch, covered with mud and leaves. They managed to wake the offender up who responded by behaving aggressively towards them. The offender told the police officers not to touch him, pointed his finger at them and hurled vulgarities at them. When the victim told the offender to mind his language, the offender uttered an expletive and slapped the victim once on his left cheek. The medical report stated that the victim sustained tenderness over his left cheek and abrasion over the left shin. At first instance, the offender was sentenced to one week’s imprisonment by the district judge. On appeal against sentence by the prosecution, the High Court held that the sentence imposed was manifestly inadequate and increased it to ten weeks’ imprisonment.

24     The High Court commented that police officers frequently endanger their lives and risk their personal safety in the discharge of their _duties_ to protect society by maintaining law and order. Police officers must therefore be assured of adequate protection and vindication by the law against behaviour that might compromise the effective discharge of their duties.[\[note: 1\]](#Ftn_1)

25     The High Court proceeded to formulate a sentencing framework for s 332 PC cases involving police officers. This sentencing framework, which is set out above,[\[note: 2\]](#Ftn_2) comprises three broad sentencing bands. The first sentencing band or Category 1 applies in cases of lesser harm and lower culpability and attracts fines or sentences of up to one year’s imprisonment.

26     The High Court determined that the factual matrix in _Jeffrey Yeo_ fell within Category 1. The harm which the police officer sustained was slight and besides the fact that the respondent was drunk, vulgar and a nuisance, there were no other factors that increased his culpability. At the time the police officers approached the offender, he was lying asleep on a grass patch near a canal next to a road and was not causing trouble. There was no member of the public in the vicinity. Further, the incident happened at about 3.41am in the morning at the side of a canal and out of public view and hearing. In those circumstances, there would be no prospect of a possible erosion of public respect for the authority of the police such as would justify a more severe sentence.[\[note: 3\]](#Ftn_3)

27     The High Court noted that the sentencing norm for cases of causing hurt to police officers under s 332 PC in Category 1 is a custodial sentence of two to nine months’ imprisonment. Fines should be meted out only in very exceptional cases, where the offending act ranks the lowest in the harm-and-culpability spectrum, for instance, involving a very young offender shoving a police officer lightly in a one-off incident, away from the public’s eyes and hearing and pleading guilty early.[\[note: 4\]](#Ftn_4)

#### Analysing the main harm and culpability factors in the present case

28     In the present case, the harm caused to the victim was slight and clearly falls within Category 1 for lesser harm. Similar to the victim in _Jeffrey Yeo_, Cpl Islam sustained a minor injury – contusion of his perineum for which he was given two days’ of medical leave. I do however accept the Prosecution’s submission that this injury or harm is slightly higher than the harm caused to the victim in _Jeffrey Yeo’s_ case. There was no further harm caused generally. For example, the was no erosion of public respect for the authority of the police as the offence had occurred in the Regional Lockup, out of public view and hearing.

29     Likewise, the Accused’s culpability was similar to that of the offender in _Jeffrey Yeo_ and falls squarely within Category 1. While the Accused’s culpability is assessed to be relatively low, I agreed with the Prosecution that it was comparatively higher than that of the offender in _Jeffrey Yeo’s_ case. The Accused was drunk and making a nuisance of herself at the Coffeeshop prior to the arrival of the police officers. She was ushered out of the Coffeeshop by the police officers, but impervious to police presence, she continued with her rowdy behaviour towards bystanders outside the Coffeeshop. She was arrested and placed in the police vehicle. In the police vehicle, the Accused persisted in disobeying police instructions and was aggressive towards the officers. She struggled with them and had to be held still by SSS Dhana throughout the journey. Additionally, she landed a kick on Cpl Islam’s rear body whilst inside the police vehicle. This formed the basis of the TIC charge under s 332 PC. While this TIC charge was part of the same encounter with the police officers, it constituted a separate incident of causing hurt to Cpl Islam to deter him from his duty, which increased the Accused’s overall culpability.

30     In terms of offender-specific factors, I noted that the Accused has unrelated antecedents for which fines were imposed. I have also given due credit to the Accused’s early plea of guilt.

31     All considered, I concluded that a fine in these circumstances for the offence under s 332 PC would be wholly inappropriate. The custodial threshold had been crossed. I agreed with the Prosecution that while the facts of this case are broadly analogous to that in _Jeffrey Yeo’s_ case, a slightly higher sentence was warranted. A term of 12 weeks’ imprisonment is fair and appropriate in the circumstances.

### s 6(1) POHA offence

32     The Prosecution submitted for a sentence of one week’s imprisonment for the s 6(1) POHA charge. They relied on four sentencing precedents for the proposition that the custodial threshold is crossed in this case. I found that the precedents tendered by the Prosecution do not necessarily support their submissions. In fact, imprisonment terms were imposed in only two of the cases and the facts of those cases are clearly distinguishable. The details of the case precedents are as follows.

#### Sentencing precedents

33      **_PP v Ng Eong Chien_** The offender pleaded guilty to two charges under s 6(1) POHA and s 353 PC. Two other similar charges under s 6(1) POHA were taken into consideration for the purposes of sentencing. The offender was sentenced to one week’s imprisonment for the s 6(1) POHA charge and three weeks’ imprisonment for the s 353 PC charge with sentences to run consecutively. The total sentence was four weeks’ imprisonment. The appeal against sentence filed by offender was dismissed.

34     In this case, the offender was passed out by the side of the road after a drinking bout. He was awakened by police officers. When asked for his particulars, he shouted vulgarities at the officers and tried to walk away. The offender pushed away an officer who tried to stop him. He also hurled vulgarities at the officer. The verbal abuse continued when he was placed under arrest and put in the patrol car. The Court noted that the offender had a number of criminal antecedents which though not directly relevant served to underscore that the offender was not a first time offender. In determining that the custodial threshold had been crossed for the s 6(1) POHA charge, the Court noted that the offender had TIC charges of a similar nature.

35      **_PP v Rasaruddin Bin Abdul Rahaman_** The offender pleaded guilty to one s 6(1) POHA offence and one s 353 PC charge. He was sentenced to one week’s imprisonment for the s 6(1) POHA charge and two weeks’ imprisonment for the s 353 PC charge. The sentences were ordered to run concurrently making a total sentence of two weeks’ imprisonment. On appeal filed by the Prosecution, the sentence for the s 353 PC charge was increased to 8 weeks’ imprisonment and ordered to run consecutively giving a total of nine weeks imprisonment.

36     The facts revealed that the offender was about to be released from prison when he was discovered with several unofficial documents in his possession. He was informed by the victim, a prison officer, that he was not allowed to take the documents with him. The offender was not happy and uttered an expletive directed at the victim. The prosecution submitted for both a custodial sentence and a fine for the s 6(1) POHA charge. The sentencing court in imposing a short custodial sentence commented that although the offender had no similar antecedents, due to his multiple previous convictions and the fact that the offences were committed within the prison on the day of his release, a short custodial sentence was warranted to meet the need for both general and specific deterrence.

37      **_PP v Leong Yin Teng Coretta and ors_**. The offender Lim claimed trial to one charge under s 332 PC r/w s 34 PC and one charge under s 6(1) POHA. The offender Lim was convicted on both charges and sentenced to 10 months’ imprisonment for the s 332 PC offence and fined $2,500 in default 10 days’ imprisonment for the s 6(1) POHA charge. The appeal against conviction and sentence by the offender was dismissed.

38     The offender Lim was at a club with his friends and was intoxicated. The victim, a police officer in plainclothes, approached the group and identified himself as a police officer. The victim questioned them if they were involved in a fight. The offender Lim became unhappy at being questioned and hurled vulgarities at the victim. When the victim tried to effect arrest, offender Lim punched him on the face and head at least three times. The sentencing court stated that the fine of $2,500 which fell in the mid-range of the maximum prescribed fine was appropriate on the facts of the case.

39      **_PP v Navinthiren Moses s/o Krishna_** The offender pleaded guilty to two charges under s 332 PC and one charge under s 6(1) POHA. He was sentenced to ten weeks’ imprisonment and 15 weeks’ imprisonment to run concurrently for each of the s 332 PC offences, and fined $2,000 in default one week’s imprisonment for the s 6(1) POHA offence. The appeal against sentence was discontinued.

40     The offender and his friends were gathered at a barbeque pit to celebrate the offender’s birthday. The offender had consumed alcohol. Police received several complaints that the group was noisy. The victim and her colleagues arrived at the scene in response to the complaints. The officers advised the group to be quieter. An altercation ensued between the offender, his two friends and the police officers. During this altercation, the offender slapped away the victim’s hand and shouted vulgarities at her. The court in imposing a non-custodial sentence for the s 6(1) POHA offence explained that it was not a case of prolonged abuse and this was the first offence for the offender.

41     I found the following decision in _PP v Chua Kok Thye_ <span class="citation">\[2019\] SGDC 125</span> to be instructive as well.

42      **_PP v Chua Kok Thye_** The offender pleaded guilty to one charge under the Societies Act, Cap 311 and one charge under s 6(1) POHA. He was sentenced to two weeks’ imprisonment for the charge under the Societies Act and a fine of S$5,000 for the s 6(1) POHA charge. The offender’s appeal against sentence was dismissed.

43     The offender was in a club drinking alcohol with his business partners and friends. He was repeatedly shouting a slogan which was a chant of a secret society. The victim, a police officer, approached the offender and identified himself. The victim asked the offender to follow him. The offender refused and started to behave aggressively. A few other police officers came over to assist in the arrest of the offender. The offender put up a violent struggle but was eventually restrained and escorted out of the club. Whilst being led out of the club, the offender uttered expletives in the Hokkien language, directed at the victim’s mother. The offender did this repeatedly, despite the victim warning him to stop. The offender was charged under s 6(1) POHA.

44     In calibrating sentence, the Court observed that such an offence under s 6(1) POHA would usually attract a fine of between $3,000 to $4,000 where (1) vulgarities were directed at a public servant; (ii) there are no other accompanying offences (e.g. no use of criminal force against the public servant concerned); (iii) the offender pleads guilty; and (iv) the offender is untraced for antecedents. In sentencing the offender to the maximum fine, which was the sentence sought by the Prosecution, the Court highlighted that the manner in which the offence was committed involved the offender repeatedly directing expletives at the police officer despite being warned to stop. The aggravating factors of committing the offence in an intoxicated state and whilst on bail warranted the maximum fine prescribed for the offence. The offender was also traced for a dated conviction in 1994 under s 20 of the he Miscellaneous Offences (Public Order and Nuisance) Act.

45     The precedents cited above suggest that the custodial threshold is crossed only when an offender, who has antecedents which may or may not be directly relevant to the fresh offences committed, engages in prolonged abuse directed at a public servant which may also form the subject matter of similar or related charges which may be proceeded with or TIC.

46     In the circumstances, I was not persuaded that the present case warranted a custodial sentence. While the facts demonstrate that the Accused was uncooperative and aggressive, the facts do not suggest that the verbal abuse was prolonged or sustained. Unlike the offenders in _Ng Eong Chien_ and _Rasaruddin_, the Accused does not have numerous antecedents either. I note that there are no TIC charges under s 6(1) POHA. While there is a s 332 PC TIC charge, I have not placed any weight on it in calibrating the appropriate sentence for the s 6(1) POHA charge to avoid double counting as this charge has already been taken into consideration in calibrating the sentence for the s 332 PC proceeded charge. In the premises, a moderate fine of $3,000 in default two weeks’ imprisonment would be appropriate.

## Conclusion

47     The degree of harm and culpability present in the offence under s 332 PC, firmly tipped the sentence over the custodial threshold. There were no exceptional factors to merit a fine only. The Accused was sentenced to 12 weeks’ imprisonment for this charge. As for the offence under s 6(1) POHA, for the reasons set out above, a moderate fine was in my view adequate to meet the sentencing objectives in this case. The Accused was fined $3,000 in default two weeks’ imprisonment for this offence. The total sentence is 12 weeks’ imprisonment and a fine of $3,000 in default two weeks’ imprisonment. The sentences imposed are not manifestly excessive.

48     The Accused being dissatisfied with the sentence imposed has filed this appeal. The execution of the sentences of fine and imprisonment have been stayed pending the appeal. The Accused is presently released on bail.

* * *
